title: Aluminum Hits 3-year High
summary: Aluminum increased to 2999.00 USD/T, the highest since April 2022. Over the past 4 weeks, Aluminum gained 3.64%, and in the last 12 months, it increased 18.54%. The price rise reflects tightening supply conditions.

title: Aluminium hits $3,000 after 3 years as supply tightens
summary: Aluminium prices hit $3,000 per tonne for the first time in over three years due to tightening supply. The surge raises questions on investment strategies amid ongoing market dynamics. No further details on specific drivers provided in the snippet.

title: Move over gold and silver: Copper, aluminium head for monster rally in 2026; household goods to get costlier
summary: Aluminum prices climbed past USD 3,000 a tonne for the first time in over three years, driven by supply constraints like China's smelting caps and Europe's reduced output. Demand from construction, renewables, and infrastructure remains strong, with futures up 17% last year. This rally is increasing costs for household goods like appliances.

title: Aluminum prices top $3000 for the first time since 2022 as supply risks grow
summary: Global aluminium prices surged to $3,000 per tonne, the highest in over three years. The increase is driven by China's production cap and rising demand in key sectors. Supply risks continue to support the upward trend.

title: Year-End Aluminum Ingot Inventory Alert Sounded! Domestic Inventory Buildup in Q1 2026 a Foregone Conclusion
summary: Domestic aluminum production increased 1.9% year-over-year and 4.0% month-over-month in December, driven by ongoing commissioning of new electrolytic aluminum projects in Inner Mongolia and Xinjiang. Casting volumes are expected to continue increasing before Chinese New Year, with domestic aluminum ingot inventory projected to reach around 730,000 tonnes by end-January 2026, creating inventory buildup pressure in Q1.

title: Macro policies remain positive, aluminium prices hit new highs during the week
summary: New aluminum projects in China and Indonesia continued ramping up production, with a new Inner Mongolia facility successfully powering on December 20. However, high prices suppressed downstream demand, with the operating rate of leading domestic aluminum processing enterprises falling to 59.9%, while inventory is forecast to rise to 730,000 tonnes by end-January 2026.

title: Aluminum Hits 3-year High
summary: Aluminum prices reached $2,999 per tonne, the highest level since April 2022, as China faces pressure to restrain output growth in 2026 due to approaching its 45 million ton annual production cap. The commodity gained 3.64% over the past four weeks and 18.54% over the past 12 months.

title: Aluminum Rises Past $3,000
summary: Aluminum futures in the UK surpassed $3,000 per tonne for the first time since 2022 at the turn of the year, driven by growing concerns about insufficient global supply amid structural constraints in production capacity.

title: Move over gold and silver: Copper, aluminium head for monster rally in 2026
summary: Aluminum prices climbed past $3,000 per tonne for the first time in over three years, lifted by structural supply constraints including China's smelting capacity caps and reduced European output due to high power costs. Strong long-term demand from construction, renewable energy, and infrastructure projects continues to support prices, with futures rising 17% in 2025.

title: ALUMINIUM 2026: Pioneering Sustainability and Innovation
summary: The ALUMINIUM 2026 trade fair, organized by RX Global, will take place October 6–8, 2026, in Düsseldorf, Germany, focusing on sustainability, innovation, and collaboration in the aluminum industry. It highlights secondary aluminum's role in decarbonization and advancements in metal processing, recycling, casting, automation, and surface finishing. New features include Hall 7A for semi-finished products and the Sustainability & Recycling Conference.

title: Aluminium's unifying approach to net-zero transformation
summary: Aluminum plays a central role in sustainable solutions like electric vehicles, solar panels, and infrastructure, with innovations driving net-zero goals. Alcoa and Rio Tinto are demonstrating ELYSIS zero-carbon smelting technology, while Emirates Global Aluminium introduces CelestiAL, aluminum produced using solar power, reducing carbon intensity. The industry is investing in clean energy, recycling, and carbon capture to meet rising demand sustainably.

title: ALUMINIUM 2026: Driving Innovation for a Sustainable Future
summary: ALUMINIUM 2026 emphasizes sustainability, particularly secondary aluminum for decarbonization, alongside topics like metal processing, recycling, and applications in mobility, construction, and manufacturing. Supported by Aluminium Deutschland and European Aluminium, the event serves as a platform for collaboration and innovation. It features themed pavilions and underscores aluminum's recyclability as a driver for a sustainable future.

title: Silicon, aluminum and lithium scarcity threaten green technology development
summary: A study identifies silicon, aluminum, and lithium as critical raw materials whose scarcity could hinder green technologies like solar panels and electric vehicles essential for the green transition. Published in Industry and Innovation, it stresses enhancing recycling and reuse to meet EU goals for strategic raw materials. The research highlights the dual role of countries as technology developers and material suppliers.

title: The 2026 shifting focus reshapes the US critical minerals strategy beyond rare-earth
summary: US critical minerals policy in 2026 prioritizes domestic processing, energy efficiency, and lower-cost technologies for metals like aluminum amid rising electricity demand from AI data centers. It shifts from new mines to refining and smelting alternatives to reduce emissions and power costs. This supports high-risk minerals and technologies for domestic processing in energy and manufacturing sectors.

title: HRC Steel - Price - Chart - Historical Data - News
summary: HRC Steel fell to 931.97 USD/T on January 2, 2026, down 0.32% from the previous day, though up 2.87% over the past month and 31.63% year-over-year. It is expected to trade at 949.49 USD/T by quarter-end and 1042.73 in 12 months. The page was last updated on January 3, 2026, providing historical charts and forecasts.

title: Viewpoint: US steel tariffs cause scrap supply glut
summary: US ferrous scrap prices are expected to edge up in January due to slower winter supply, but long-term steel tariffs will sustain high scrap supply and limit major increases into 2026. US flat and long steel prices climbed in December, while Turkish rebar prices fell to $559/t. Domestic HRC prices in India rose to 47,250 rupees/t ($525/t) ex-Mumbai by late December amid mill hikes and import duty extensions.

title: Steel - Price - Chart - Historical Data - News
summary: Steel fell to 3,096 CNY/T on December 31, 2025, down 0.32% daily, 0.45% monthly, and 5.70% year-over-year. Recent news highlights steel rebar futures set to drop 7% in 2025 amid soft demand, and rises on improving profitability from falling input costs. The page was last updated on January 3, 2026.

title: China's Baosteel hikes January 2026 prices due to rising raw material costs, market optimism
summary: China's Baosteel raised prices for January 2026, ending three months of flat pricing, driven by rising raw material costs and market optimism. Steel demand in China remains weak despite the hike.

title: U.S. Steelmakers Prep for $1.6 Billion in 1Q Project Starts
summary: U.S. steelmakers like U.S. Steel and Cleveland-Cliffs are preparing over $1.6 billion in steel-manufacturing projects set to begin construction in Q1 2026, focusing on capacity expansions and restarts to meet rising demand. Key projects include restarting Furnace B at U.S. Steel's Granite City Steel Works and Cleveland-Cliffs replacing furnaces at Butler Steel Works for efficiency gains. Nippon Steel commits to no closures of U.S. Steel facilities before 2035.

title: Viewpoint: US steel tariffs cause scrap supply glut
summary: US steel tariffs are leading to a glut in ferrous scrap supply as North American dealers flood the market, expected to continue into 2026 due to protected US steel prices and global dynamics like China's influence. US steel prices are rising while Turkish prices fall, encouraging domestic scrap sales. Long-term, tariffs prevent major scrap price increases despite seasonal upticks.

title: Steel development minister sets agenda for growth in 2026
summary: Nigeria's Steel Development Minister outlines 2026 plans to revitalize Ajaokuta Steel Complex via MoUs with Chinese investors and original manufacturers, alongside $500 million in mini-LNG plants for power supply. Investments include a $400 million steel plant by Inner Galaxy Group in Ewekoro and Orbit Galvanised Steel Plant commissioning, boosting local production, jobs, and capacity.

title: Steel Industry praises Trump tariffs, farmers feel the strain
summary: US steel industry leaders praise Trump tariffs for countering global oversupply and subsidies from countries like China, benefiting domestic production without shortages. W&W AFCO Steel, focused on infrastructure, reports positive impacts from tariffs driving fairer market dynamics. The company sources only domestic steel for projects like bridges and stadiums.

title: Hertha Metals to break ground on commercial steel plant in 2026
summary: Hertha Metals plans to break ground in 2026 on a commercial steel plant producing 30 tonnes daily, creating 60 permanent jobs and 550 construction positions. The project advances innovative steel production capacity in Houston.

title: Sustainability Indicators Report 2025
summary: The World Steel Association released its Sustainability Indicators Report 2025, presenting nineteen sustainability indicators for the steel industry along with a historical overview. This report underscores the industry's commitment to transparent data disclosure, continual improvement in environmental performance, and pathways to reduce CO2 emissions. It highlights steel's role in the circular economy and sustainable practices like water management and air quality control.

title: EU's carbon border tax on heavy industry goods goes into effect, risking trade escalation
summary: The EU's Carbon Border Adjustment Mechanism (CBAM) took effect on 1 January 2026, requiring steel and aluminium exporters to pay for CO2 emissions linked to their production. This measure aims to protect EU manufacturers from carbon leakage and encourage global adoption of carbon pricing and cleaner production methods. Critics argue it acts as protectionism, potentially raising costs and complicating trade.

title: Roadmap for Iron & Steel Manufacturing
source: AIST Association for Iron & Steel Technology
summary: AIST unveiled the Roadmap for Iron and Steel Manufacturing, funded by the U.S. Department of Commerce and NIST, outlining technologies, infrastructure, and workforce strategies to decarbonize the U.S. iron and steel industry. The roadmap focuses on revolutionizing U.S. global leadership for a sustainable industrial supply chain. It emphasizes innovation to strengthen competitiveness while addressing environmental challenges.

title: Ivanhoe Mines Announces First Anode Production from Kamoa-Kakula Copper Smelter
summary: Ivanhoe Mines has begun first anode production at the Kamoa-Kakula copper smelter in the Democratic Republic of Congo, with the ramp-up continuing throughout 2026 to reach full capacity of 500,000 tonnes per annum by year-end. Kamoa-Kakula's copper production is estimated at 380,000 to 420,000 tonnes in 2026, representing about 80% of smelter capacity, with sales expected 20,000 tonnes higher due to destocking of concentrate inventory. Dewatering of Kakula Mine is complete ahead of schedule, enabling higher-grade mining with head grades rising from 3.5% to 4.0% copper by end of Q1 2026.

title: Ivanhoe Mines begins copper anode production at new Congo smelter
summary: Ivanhoe Mines started copper anode production at the Kamoa-Kakula direct-to-blister smelter in the DRC on December 29, 2025, five weeks after heat-up and one week after first concentrate feed. The smelter has a steady-state capacity of 500,000 tonnes per annum of 99.7% pure copper anode, the largest in Africa once fully ramped up by year-end 2026. 2026 production is projected at 380,000-420,000 tonnes, with sales boosted by destocking unsold concentrate amid high copper prices.

title: Exclusive interview with José Jiménez from Atlantic Copper - Transforming e-scrap
summary: Atlantic Copper, a leading European copper producer, discusses its CirCular project, which valorizes e-scrap from recycled electronics using advanced metallurgical processes and circular economy principles. The initiative addresses resource scarcity, reduces landfill waste and CO₂ emissions, and aligns with the EU Green Deal, with production set to start in the second half of 2026. Sponsorship of IERC 2026 underscores their commitment to innovation, collaboration, and sustainability in copper production for electrification and renewable energy.

title: Copper as the Strategic Metal of the 21st Century
summary: Copper is highlighted as essential for the energy transition, electric vehicles, AI infrastructure, and decarbonization, with surging demand outpacing supply and leading to deficits by 2026. Geopolitical factors like U.S. tariffs and China's policies intensify competition, while ESG practices and recycling gain importance for sustainable production. Investors are advised to consider ETFs and mining stocks amid these opportunities and risks.

title: Teck Announces Construction of Highland Valley Copper Mine Life Extension to Proceed
summary: Teck Resources has approved construction for the Highland Valley Copper Mine Life Extension Project, extending Canada's largest copper mine's life from 2028 to 2046 with average annual production of 132,000 tonnes. The project supports Teck's goal to double copper output by decade's end, driven by energy transition demand, and includes infrastructure upgrades with all major permits secured. It promises economic benefits, jobs, and strengthened critical minerals supply.

title: Rio Tinto's Nuton technology produces first copper
summary: Rio Tinto's innovative Nuton technology has produced its first copper, achieving the lowest U.S. mine-to-metal carbon footprint of 0.82 kg CO₂-e per kg copper. This breakthrough enhances sustainable copper production through advanced leaching processes. It positions Rio Tinto as a leader in low-emission critical minerals for the energy transition.

title: Nickel - Price - Chart - Historical Data - News
summary: Nickel fell to 16,760 USD/T on January 2, 2026, down 0.48% from the previous day, though it has risen 12.97% over the past month and 10.27% year-over-year. UK nickel futures surged to $15,600 per tonne, the highest since May, after hitting four-year lows, as markets reconsider oversupply views. Indonesia proposed a 34% reduction in nickel output for 2026 to address oversupply and deteriorating ore grades.

title: Nickel Prices Jump After Top Producer Indonesia Signals 2026 Output Cut
summary: Nickel prices jumped to their highest since March after Indonesia announced plans to cut 2026 nickel production to balance supply and demand amid rising LME inventories. Spot nickel rose to $16,500 a tonne on Tuesday from $15,800 on Monday, with the three-month LME contract up 6.4% on Dec. 30. The move aims to curb surplus, support prices, and limit environmental impact, similar to DRC's cobalt actions.

title: Nickel Higher on Mine Suspension
summary: Nickel rose 1.6% to $16,910, breaking 14-month highs following the suspension of Vale's Indonesia mine. Recent support comes from Indonesia's announcement to cut nickel ore output by a third in 2026 to support prices. This occurs amid broader base metal movements, with demand in China remaining resilient.

title: Nickel reaches 14-month high following Vale Indonesia's halt to mining
summary: Nickel prices hit a 14-month high after Vale Indonesia suspended mining operations due to a delay in annual production plan approval. The LME three-month nickel rose 1.4% to $16,875 per metric ton. Indonesia's planned cut in ore production by a third by 2026 further supported prices amid previous oversupply.

title: Nickel Prices Jump After Top Producer Indonesia Signals 2026 Output Cut
summary: Indonesia plans to cut nickel production quotas in 2026 by adjusting miner outputs to balance supply and demand, following sharp rises in LME inventories. Nickel prices surged to $16,500 per tonne on spot markets and up 6.4% on LME contracts. The move aims to curb surplus, support prices, and limit environmental impact, similar to DRC's cobalt strategy.

title: Nickel prices surge as Indonesia plans one-third cut in 2026 RKAB quotas
summary: Indonesia's 2026 nickel ore mining quota is set at 250 million metric tonnes, a one-third reduction from 379 million tonnes in 2025, sparking supply concerns and price surges. SHFE nickel futures gained over Yuan 15,000/tonne recently. This creates a projected 52 million tonne ore gap versus estimated consumption of 327 million wmt.

title: Nickel Higher on Mine Suspension
summary: Nickel rose 1.6% to $16,910, breaking 14-month highs due to Vale Indonesia's mine suspension and the government's plan to cut nickel ore output by a third in 2026. The move aims to support prices amid prior oversupply. Other metals like aluminum also gained on supply constraints.

title: Nickel Industries says South Korea's Sphere to buy 10% stake in Indonesian project
summary: South Korea's Sphere Corp will acquire a 10% stake in Nickel Industries' Excelsior Nickel Cobalt HPAL project in Indonesia's Central Sulawesi, capable of producing MHP, nickel sulphate, and cathode. The deal values the project at $2.4 billion and includes offtake agreements, amid soaring nickel prices from Indonesia's output cut plans. Funding is expected early Q1 2026.

title: Vale Indonesia halts nickel mining on delayed work plan approval
summary: Vale Indonesia suspended nickel mining operations due to delayed approval of its annual work plan. The company, a major nickel miner investing in HPAL plants, expects approval soon without long-term disruption. This halt contributed to recent nickel price surges.

title: South Korea's Sphere to invest in Indonesian Ni project
summary: South Korea's Sphere will invest in a 10% stake of Nickel Industries' Excelsior nickel project in Indonesia, with production starting April-June 2026 and offtake of 10% nickel cathode. Indonesian MHP capacity is expanding significantly, with prices recently assessed at $132.50/mtu. The investment aligns with rising nickel prices from planned output cuts.

title: Ultrahigh-Nickel Cathodes Near Density Limit
summary: Researchers have developed ultrahigh-nickel single-crystalline oxide cathodes that achieve unprecedented particle sizes with pristine structural order, addressing capacity degradation and instability in lithium-ion batteries. These cathodes approach the theoretical density limit, enhancing volumetric capacity, cycle life, and safety for electric vehicles. The innovation supports industrial scalability and sustainable energy storage solutions.

title: Decreasing the Scope 3 Emissions of Chemical Synthesis with CataNiTek Nickel Catalysts
summary: CataNiTek's platform technology uses well-defined nickel(0) complexes as effective homogeneous catalysts, challenging precious metal catalysts in synthesizing agrochemicals, pharmaceuticals, and fine chemicals. This innovation reduces Scope 3 emissions in chemical synthesis and enables new synthetic methodologies accessible to bench chemists. It promotes sustainable chemical production by lowering environmental impact.

title: Nickel reaches 14-month high following Vale Indonesia's halt to mining
summary: Nickel prices surged to a 14-month high of $16,945 per metric ton after Vale Indonesia suspended mining operations due to a delay in production plan approval. This follows Indonesia's announcement to cut ore production by a third by 2026 to support prices amid oversupply. The event highlights sustainability efforts through regulated supply in nickel production.

title: Copper Cables: Antitrust Launches Investigation into Alleged Cartel
summary: Italy's Antitrust Authority has initiated an investigation into major low-voltage copper cable manufacturers, including Prysmian Cavi e Sistemi Italia Srl and others, for alleged price-fixing since 2005. Officials conducted inspections at company offices, supported by Guardia di Finanza. Prysmian shares dropped 1.26% following the news, though analysts view the impact as negligible due to the small market share.
